element.short: A person with a  formal responsibility in the provisioning of healthcare or related services
element.definition: A person who is directly or indirectly involved in the provisioning of healthcare.
element.comments: Note that a cab driver no longer fits the bill. You probably would be interested in the organization rather than the individual?
element.requirements: Need to track doctors, staff, locums etc. for both healthcare practitioners, funders, etc.

element.short: A identifier for the person as this agent
element.definition: An identifier that applies to this person in this role.
element.requirements: Often, specific identities are assigned for the agent.

element.short: usual | official | temp | secondary (If known)
element.definition: The purpose of this identifier.
element.comments: This is labeled as
because applications should not mistake a temporary id for a permanent one. Applications can assume that an identifier is permanent unless it explicitly says that it is temporary.
element.requirements: Allows the appropriate identifier for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of identifiers.

binding.name: IdentifierUse
binding.description: Identifies the purpose for this identifier, if known

element.short: Description of identifier
element.definition: A coded type for the identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose.
element.comments: Where the system is known, a type is unnecessary because the type is always part of the system definition. However systems often need to handle identifiers where the system is not known. There is not a 1:1 relationship between type and system, since many different systems have the same type.
element.requirements: Allows users to make use of identifiers when the identifier system is not known.

binding.name: IdentifierType
binding.description: A coded type for an identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose

element.short: Code defined by a terminology system
element.definition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
element.comments: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations, or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the V3 Core Principles for more information.  Ordering of codings is undefined and SHALL not be used to infer meaning.
element.requirements: Allows for translations and alternate encodings within a code system.  Also supports communication of the same instance to systems requiring different encodings.

element.short: Identity of the terminology system
element.definition: The identification of the code system that defines the meaning of the symbol in the code.
element.comments: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...).  OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should de-reference to some definition that establish the system clearly and unambiguously.
element.requirements: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol.

element.short: Version of the system - if relevant
element.definition: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured. and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.
element.comments: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

element.short: Symbol in syntax defined by the system
element.definition: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).
element.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

element.short: Representation defined by the system
element.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.
element.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

mapping.map: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

element.short: If this code was chosen directly by the user
element.definition: Indicates that this code was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
element.comments: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations.
element.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact code was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

element.short: Plain text representation of the concept
element.definition: A human language representation of the concept as seen/selected/uttered by the user who entered the data and/or which represents the intended meaning of the user.
element.comments: Very often the text is the same as a displayName of one of the codings.
element.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human using them, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source.

mapping.map: C*E.9. But note many systems use C*E.2 for this

element.short: The namespace for the identifier
element.definition: Establishes the namespace in which set of possible id values is unique.
element.requirements: There are many sequences of identifiers.  To perform matching, we need to know what sequence we're dealing with. The system identifies a particular sequence or set of unique identifiers.
element.exampleUri: http://www.acme.com/identifiers/patient or urn:ietf:rfc:3986 if the id itself is a full uri

element.short: The value that is unique
element.definition: The portion of the identifier typically displayed to the user and which is unique within the context of the system.
element.comments: If the value is a full URI, then the system SHALL be urn:ietf:rfc:3986.

mapping.map: II.extension or II.root if system indicates OID or GUID (Or Role.id.extension or root)

element.short: Time period when id is/was valid for use
element.definition: Time period during which identifier is/was valid for use.

element.short: Starting time with inclusive boundary
element.definition: The start of the period. The boundary is inclusive.
element.comments: If the low element is missing, the meaning is that the low boundary is not known.

element.short: End time with inclusive boundary, if not ongoing
element.definition: The end of the period. If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing.
element.comments: The high value includes any matching date/time. i.e. 2012-02-03T10:00:00 is in a period that has a end value of 2012-02-03.

element.short: Organization that issued id (may be just text)
element.definition: Organization that issued/manages the identifier.
element.comments: The reference may be just a text description of the assigner.

mapping.map: II.assigningAuthorityName but note that this is an improper use by the definition of the field.  Also Role.scoper

element.short: Relative, internal or absolute URL reference
element.definition: A reference to a location at which the other resource is found. The reference may be a relative reference, in which case it is relative to the service base URL, or an absolute URL that resolves to the location where the resource is found. The reference may be version specific or not. If the reference is not to a FHIR RESTful server, then it should be assumed to be version specific. Internal fragment references (start with '#') refer to contained resources.
element.comments: Using absolute URLs provides a stable scalable approach suitable for a cloud/web context, while using relative/logical references provides a flexible approach suitable for use when trading across closed eco-system boundaries.   Absolute URLs do not need to point to a FHIR RESTful server, though this is the preferred approach. If the url conforms to the structure
then it should be assumed that the reference is to a FHIR RESTful server.

element.short: Text alternative for the resource
element.definition: Plain text narrative that identifies the resource in addition to the resource reference.
element.comments: This is generally not the same as the Resource.text of the referenced resource.  The purpose is to identify what's being referenced, not to fully describe it.

element.short: A name associated with the person
element.definition: A name associated with the person.
element.requirements: Contact persons need to be identified by name, but it is uncommon to need details about multiple other names for that person.

element.short: usual | official | temp | nickname | anonymous | old | maiden
element.definition: Identifies the purpose for this name.
element.comments: This is labeled as
because applications should not mistake a temporary or old name etc for a current/permanent one. Applications can assume that a name is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
element.requirements: Allows the appropriate name for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of names.

binding.name: NameUse
binding.description: The use of a human name

mapping.map: XPN.7, but often indicated by which field contains the name

element.short: Text representation of the full name
element.definition: A full text representation of the name.
element.comments: Can provide both a text representation and structured parts.
element.requirements: A renderable, unencoded form.

element.short: Family name (often called 'Surname')
element.definition: The part of a name that links to the genealogy. In some cultures (e.g. Eritrea) the family name of a son is the first name of his father.
element.comments: For family name, hyphenated names such as
are a single name, but names with spaces such as
are broken into multiple parts.

element.short: Given names (not always 'first'). Includes middle names
element.definition: Given name.
element.comments: If only initials are recorded, they may be used in place of the full name.  Not called
since given names do not always come first.

element.short: Parts that come before the name
element.definition: Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status, etc. and that appears at the start of the name.

element.short: Parts that come after the name
element.definition: Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status, etc. and that appears at the end of the name.

element.short: Time period when name was/is in use
element.definition: Indicates the period of time when this name was valid for the named person.
element.requirements: Allows names to be placed in historical context.

element.short: Starting time with inclusive boundary
element.definition: The start of the period. The boundary is inclusive.
element.comments: If the low element is missing, the meaning is that the low boundary is not known.

element.short: End time with inclusive boundary, if not ongoing
element.definition: The end of the period. If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing.
element.comments: The high value includes any matching date/time. i.e. 2012-02-03T10:00:00 is in a period that has a end value of 2012-02-03.

element.short: A contact detail for the practitioner
element.definition: A contact detail for the practitioner, e.g. a telephone number or an email address.
element.comments: Person may have multiple ways to be contacted with different uses or applicable periods.  May need to have options for contacting the person urgently, and also to help with identification.
element.requirements: Need to know how to reach a practitioner.

element.short: phone | fax | email | url
element.definition: Telecommunications form for contact point - what communications system is required to make use of the contact.

element.short: The actual contact point details
element.definition: The actual contact point details, in a form that is meaningful to the designated communication system (i.e. phone number or email address).
element.comments: Additional out of band data such as extensions, or notes about use of the contact are sometimes included in the value.
element.requirements: Need to support legacy numbers that are not in a tightly controlled format.

element.short: home | work | temp | old | mobile - purpose of this contact point
element.definition: Identifies the purpose for the contact point.
element.comments: This is labeled as

because applications should not mistake a temporary or old contact etc for a current/permanent one. Applications can assume that a contact is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
element.requirements: Need to track the way a person uses this contact, so a user can choose which is appropriate for their purpose.

mapping.map: XTN.2 - but often indicated by field

element.short: Time period when the contact point was/is in use
element.definition: Time period when the contact point was/is in use.

element.short: Starting time with inclusive boundary
element.definition: The start of the period. The boundary is inclusive.
element.comments: If the low element is missing, the meaning is that the low boundary is not known.

element.short: End time with inclusive boundary, if not ongoing
element.definition: The end of the period. If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing.
element.comments: The high value includes any matching date/time. i.e. 2012-02-03T10:00:00 is in a period that has a end value of 2012-02-03.

element.short: Where practitioner can be found/visited
element.definition: The postal address where the practitioner can be found or visited or to which mail can be delivered.
element.requirements: Need to keep track where the practitioner can found during work or for directing mail.

element.short: home | work | temp | old - purpose of this address
element.definition: The purpose of this address.
element.comments: This is labeled as

because applications should not mistake a temporary or old address etc for a current/permanent one. Applications can assume that an address is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
element.requirements: Allows an appropriate address to be chosen from a list of many.

element.short: Text representation of the address
element.definition: A full text representation of the address.
element.comments: Can provide both a text representation and parts.
element.requirements: A renderable, unencoded form.

mapping.map: XAD.1 + XAD.2 + XAD.3 + XAD.4 + XAD.5 + XAD.6

element.short: Street name, number, direction & P.O. Box etc
element.definition: This component contains the house number, apartment number, street name, street direction,  P.O. Box number, delivery hints, and similar address information.
element.requirements: home | work | temp | old - purpose of this address.

mapping.map: XAD.1 + XAD.2 (note: XAD.1 and XAD.2 have different meanings for a company address than for a person address)

element.short: Name of city, town etc.
element.definition: The name of the city, town, village or other community or delivery center.

element.short: Sub-unit of country (abreviations ok)
element.definition: Sub-unit of a country with limited sovereignty in a federally organized country. A code may be used if codes are in common use (i.e. US 2 letter state codes).

element.short: Postal code for area
element.definition: A postal code designating a region defined by the postal service.

element.short: Country (can be ISO 3166 3 letter code)
element.definition: Country - a nation as commonly understood or generally accepted.
element.comments: ISO 3166 3 letter codes can be used in place of a full country name.

element.short: Time period when address was/is in use
element.definition: Time period when address was/is in use.
element.requirements: Allows addresses to be placed in historical context.

element.short: Starting time with inclusive boundary
element.definition: The start of the period. The boundary is inclusive.
element.comments: If the low element is missing, the meaning is that the low boundary is not known.

element.short: End time with inclusive boundary, if not ongoing
element.definition: The end of the period. If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing.
element.comments: The high value includes any matching date/time. i.e. 2012-02-03T10:00:00 is in a period that has a end value of 2012-02-03.

element.short: male | female | other | unknown
element.definition: Administrative Gender - the gender that the person is considered to have for administration and record keeping purposes.
element.requirements: Needed to address the person correctly.

binding.name: AdministrativeGender
binding.description: The gender of a person used for administrative purposes

element.short: The date  of birth for the practitioner
element.definition: The date of birth for the practitioner.
element.requirements: Needed for identification.

element.short: Image of the person
element.definition: Image of the person.
element.requirements: Many EHR systems have the capability to capture an image of patients and personnel. Fits with newer social media usage too.

element.short: Mime type of the content, with charset etc.
element.definition: Identifies the type of the data in the attachment and allows a method to be chosen to interpret or render the data. Includes mime type parameters such as charset where appropriate.
element.requirements: Processors of the data need to be able to know how to interpret the data.

binding.name: MimeType
binding.description: The mime type of an attachment

mapping.map: ED.2+ED.3/RP.2+RP.3. Note conversion may be needed if old style values are being used

element.short: Human language of the content (BCP-47)
element.definition: The human language of the content. The value can be any valid value according to BCP 47.
element.requirements: Users need to be able to choose between the languages in a set of attachments.

element.short: Data inline, base64ed
element.definition: The actual data of the attachment - a sequence of bytes. In XML, represented using base64.
element.comments: The base64-encoded data SHALL be expressed in the same character set as the base resource XML or JSON.
element.requirements: The data needs to able to be transmitted inline.

element.short: Uri where the data can be found
element.definition: An alternative location where the data can be accessed.
element.comments: If both data and url are provided, the url SHALL point to the same content as the data contains. Urls may be relative references or may reference transient locations such as a wrapping envelope using cid: though this has ramifications for using signatures. Relative URLs are interpreted relative to the service url, like a resource reference, rather than relative to the resource itself. If a URL is provided, it SHALL resolve to actual data.
element.requirements: The data needs to be transmitted by reference.

mapping.map: RP.1+RP.2 - if they refer to a URL (see v2.6)

element.short: Number of bytes of content (if url provided)
element.definition: The number of bytes of data that make up this attachment.
element.comments: The number of bytes is redundant if the data is provided as a base64binary, but is useful if the data is provided as a url reference.
element.requirements: Representing the size allows applications to determine whether they should fetch the content automatically in advance, or refuse to fetch it at all.

element.short: Hash of the data (sha-1, base64ed )
element.definition: The calculated hash of the data using SHA-1. Represented using base64.
element.requirements: Included so that applications can verify that the contents of a location have not changed and so that a signature of the content can implicitly sign the content of an image without having to include the data in the instance or reference the url in the signature.

element.short: Label to display in place of the data
element.definition: A label or set of text to display in place of the data.
element.requirements: Applications need a label to display to a human user in place of the actual data if the data cannot be rendered or perceived by the viewer.

element.short: Date attachment was first created
element.definition: The date that the attachment was first created.
element.requirements: This is often tracked as an integrity issue for use of the attachment.

element.short: The list of Roles/Organizations that the Practitioner is associated with
element.definition: The list of Roles/Organizations that the Practitioner is associated with.

element.short: The Organization where the Practitioner performs the roles associated
element.definition: The Organization where the Practitioner performs the roles associated.

element.short: Relative, internal or absolute URL reference
element.definition: A reference to a location at which the other resource is found. The reference may be a relative reference, in which case it is relative to the service base URL, or an absolute URL that resolves to the location where the resource is found. The reference may be version specific or not. If the reference is not to a FHIR RESTful server, then it should be assumed to be version specific. Internal fragment references (start with '#') refer to contained resources.
element.comments: Using absolute URLs provides a stable scalable approach suitable for a cloud/web context, while using relative/logical references provides a flexible approach suitable for use when trading across closed eco-system boundaries.   Absolute URLs do not need to point to a FHIR RESTful server, though this is the preferred approach. If the url conforms to the structure
then it should be assumed that the reference is to a FHIR RESTful server.

element.short: Text alternative for the resource
element.definition: Plain text narrative that identifies the resource in addition to the resource reference.
element.comments: This is generally not the same as the Resource.text of the referenced resource.  The purpose is to identify what's being referenced, not to fully describe it.

element.short: Roles which this practitioner may perform
element.definition: Roles which this practitioner is authorized to perform for the organization.
element.comments: A person may have more than one role. At least one role is required.
element.requirements: Need to know what authority the practitioner has - what can they do?

binding.name: PractitionerRole
binding.description: The role a person plays representing an organization

mapping.map: PRD-1 / STF-18-job title / PRA-3-practitioner category  / PRT-4-Participation / ROL-3-role-ROL / ORC-12-ordering provider / OBR-16-ordering provider / PV1-7-attending doctor / PV1-8-referring doctor / PV1-9-consulting doctor / PV1-17-admitting doctor
(ServD maps Practitioners and Organizations via another entity, so this concept is not available)

element.short: Code defined by a terminology system
element.definition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
element.comments: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations, or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the V3 Core Principles for more information.  Ordering of codings is undefined and SHALL not be used to infer meaning.
element.requirements: Allows for translations and alternate encodings within a code system.  Also supports communication of the same instance to systems requiring different encodings.

element.short: Identity of the terminology system
element.definition: The identification of the code system that defines the meaning of the symbol in the code.
element.comments: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...).  OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should de-reference to some definition that establish the system clearly and unambiguously.
element.requirements: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol.

element.short: Version of the system - if relevant
element.definition: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured. and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.
element.comments: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

element.short: Symbol in syntax defined by the system
element.definition: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).
element.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

element.short: Representation defined by the system
element.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.
element.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

mapping.map: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

element.short: If this code was chosen directly by the user
element.definition: Indicates that this code was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
element.comments: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations.
element.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact code was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

element.short: Plain text representation of the concept
element.definition: A human language representation of the concept as seen/selected/uttered by the user who entered the data and/or which represents the intended meaning of the user.
element.comments: Very often the text is the same as a displayName of one of the codings.
element.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human using them, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source.

mapping.map: C*E.9. But note many systems use C*E.2 for this

element.short: Specific specialty of the practitioner
element.definition: Specific specialty of the practitioner.

element.short: Code defined by a terminology system
element.definition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
element.comments: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations, or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the V3 Core Principles for more information.  Ordering of codings is undefined and SHALL not be used to infer meaning.
element.requirements: Allows for translations and alternate encodings within a code system.  Also supports communication of the same instance to systems requiring different encodings.

element.comments: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...).  OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should de-reference to some definition that establish the system clearly and unambiguously.

element.comments: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

element.definition: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).
element.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

element.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

element.definition: Indicates that this code was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
element.comments: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations.
element.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact code was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

element.definition: A human language representation of the concept as seen/selected/uttered by the user who entered the data and/or which represents the intended meaning of the user.
element.comments: Very often the text is the same as a displayName of one of the codings.
element.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human using them, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source.

mapping.map: C*E.9. But note many systems use C*E.2 for this

element.short: The period during which the practitioner is authorized to perform in these role(s)
element.definition: The period during which the person is authorized to act as a practitioner in these role(s) for the organization.
element.requirements: Even after the agencies is revoked, the fact that it existed must still be recorded.

mapping.map: (ServD maps Practitioners and Organizations via another entity, so this concept is not available)

element.short: Starting time with inclusive boundary
element.definition: The start of the period. The boundary is inclusive.
element.comments: If the low element is missing, the meaning is that the low boundary is not known.

element.short: End time with inclusive boundary, if not ongoing
element.definition: The end of the period. If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing.
element.comments: The high value includes any matching date/time. i.e. 2012-02-03T10:00:00 is in a period that has a end value of 2012-02-03.

element.short: The location(s) at which this practitioner provides care
element.definition: The location(s) at which this practitioner provides care.

mapping.map:
(ServD maps Practitioners and Organizations via another entity, so this concept is not available)
However these are accessed via the Site.ServiceSite.ServiceSiteProvider record. (The Site has the location)

element.comments: This is generally not the same as the Resource.text of the referenced resource.  The purpose is to identify what's being referenced, not to fully describe it.

element.short: The list of healthcare services that this worker provides for this role's Organization/Location(s)
element.definition: The list of healthcare services that this worker provides for this role's Organization/Location(s).

element.short: Relative, internal or absolute URL reference
element.definition: A reference to a location at which the other resource is found. The reference may be a relative reference, in which case it is relative to the service base URL, or an absolute URL that resolves to the location where the resource is found. The reference may be version specific or not. If the reference is not to a FHIR RESTful server, then it should be assumed to be version specific. element.short: Text alternative for the resource
element.definition: Plain text narrative that identifies the resource in addition to the resource reference.
element.comments: This is generally not the same as the Resource.text of the referenced resource.  The purpose is to identify what's being referenced, not to fully describe it.

element.short: Qualifications obtained by training and certification
element.definition: Qualifications obtained by training and certification.

element.short: An identifier for this qualification for the practitioner
element.definition: An identifier that applies to this person's qualification in this role.
element.requirements: Often, specific identities are assigned for the qualification.

element.short: usual | official | temp | secondary (If known)
element.definition: The purpose of this identifier.
element.comments: This is labeled as
because applications should not mistake a temporary id for a permanent one. Applications can assume that an identifier is permanent unless it explicitly says that it is temporary.
element.requirements: Allows the appropriate identifier for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of identifiers.

binding.name: IdentifierUse
binding.description: Identifies the purpose for this identifier, if known

element.short: Description of identifier
element.definition: A coded type for the identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose.
element.comments: Where the system is known, a type is unnecessary because the type is always part of the system definition. However systems often need to handle identifiers where the system is not known. There is not a 1:1 relationship between type and system, since many different systems have the same type.
element.requirements: Allows users to make use of identifiers when the identifier system is not known.

binding.name: IdentifierType
binding.description: A coded type for an identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose

element.short: Code defined by a terminology system
element.definition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
element.comments: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations, or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the V3 Core Principles for more information.  Ordering of codings is undefined and SHALL not be used to infer meaning.
element.requirements: Allows for translations and alternate encodings within a code system.  Also supports communication of the same instance to systems requiring different encodings.

element.short: Identity of the terminology system
element.definition: The identification of the code system that defines the meaning of the symbol in the code.
element.comments: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...).  OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should de-reference to some definition that establish the system clearly and unambiguously.
element.requirements: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol.

element.short: Version of the system - if relevant
element.definition: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured. and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.
element.comments: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

element.short: Symbol in syntax defined by the system
element.definition: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).
element.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

element.short: Representation defined by the system
element.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.
element.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

mapping.map: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

element.short: If this code was chosen directly by the user
element.definition: Indicates that this code was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
element.comments: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations.
element.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact code was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

element.short: Plain text representation of the concept
element.definition: A human language representation of the concept as seen/selected/uttered by the user who entered the data and/or which represents the intended meaning of the user.
element.comments: Very often the text is the same as a displayName of one of the codings.
element.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human using them, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source.

mapping.map: C*E.9. But note many systems use C*E.2 for this

element.short: The namespace for the identifier
element.definition: Establishes the namespace in which set of possible id values is unique.
element.requirements: There are many sequences of identifiers.  To perform matching, we need to know what sequence we're dealing with. The system identifies a particular sequence or set of unique identifiers.
element.exampleUri: http://www.acme.com/identifiers/patient or urn:ietf:rfc:3986 if the id itself is a full uri

element.short: The value that is unique
element.definition: The portion of the identifier typically displayed to the user and which is unique within the context of the system.
element.comments: If the value is a full URI, then the system SHALL be urn:ietf:rfc:3986.

mapping.map: II.extension or II.root if system indicates OID or GUID (Or Role.id.extension or root)

element.short: Time period when id is/was valid for use
element.definition: Time period during which identifier is/was valid for use.

element.short: Starting time with inclusive boundary
element.definition: The start of the period. The boundary is inclusive.
element.comments: If the low element is missing, the meaning is that the low boundary is not known.

element.short: End time with inclusive boundary, if not ongoing
element.definition: The end of the period. If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing.
element.comments: The high value includes any matching date/time. i.e. 2012-02-03T10:00:00 is in a period that has a end value of 2012-02-03.

element.short: Organization that issued id (may be just text)
element.definition: Organization that issued/manages the identifier.
element.comments: The reference may be just a text description of the assigner.

mapping.map: II.assigningAuthorityName but note that this is an improper use by the definition of the field.  Also Role.scoper

element.short: Relative, internal or absolute URL reference
element.definition: A reference to a location at which the other resource is found. The reference may be a relative reference, in which case it is relative to the service base URL, or an absolute URL that resolves to the location where the resource is found. The reference may be version specific or not. If the reference is not to a FHIR RESTful server, then it should be assumed to be version specific. Internal fragment references (start with '#') refer to contained resources.
element.comments: Using absolute URLs provides a stable scalable approach suitable for a cloud/web context, while using relative/logical references provides a flexible approach suitable for use when trading across closed eco-system boundaries.   Absolute URLs do not need to point to a FHIR RESTful server, though this is the preferred approach. If the url conforms to the structure
then it should be assumed that the reference is to a FHIR RESTful server.

element.short: Text alternative for the resource
element.definition: Plain text narrative that identifies the resource in addition to the resource reference.
element.comments: This is generally not the same as the Resource.text of the referenced resource.  The purpose is to identify what's being referenced, not to fully describe it.

element.short: Coded representation of the qualification
element.definition: Coded representation of the qualification.

binding.name: Qualification
binding.description: Specific qualification the practitioner has to provide a service

element.short: Code defined by a terminology system
element.definition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
element.comments: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations, or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the V3 Core Principles for more information.  Ordering of codings is undefined and SHALL not be used to infer meaning.
element.requirements: Allows for translations and alternate encodings within a code system.  Also supports communication of the same instance to systems requiring different encodings.

element.definition: The identification of the code system that defines the meaning of the symbol in the code.
element.comments: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...).  OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should de-reference to some definition that establish the system clearly and unambiguously.
element.requirements: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol.

element.short: Version of the system - if relevant
element.definition: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured. and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.
element.comments: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

element.short: Symbol in syntax defined by the system
element.definition: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).
element.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

element.short: Representation defined by the system
element.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.
element.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

mapping.map: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

element.short: If this code was chosen directly by the user
element.definition: Indicates that this code was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
element.comments: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations.
element.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact code was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

element.short: Plain text representation of the concept
element.definition: A human language representation of the concept as seen/selected/uttered by the user who entered the data and/or which represents the intended meaning of the user.
element.comments: Very often the text is the same as a displayName of one of the codings.
element.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human using them, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source.

mapping.map: C*E.9. But note many systems use C*E.2 for this

element.short: Period during which the qualification is valid
element.definition: Period during which the qualification is valid.
element.requirements: Qualifications are often for a limited period of time, and can be revoked.

element.short: Starting time with inclusive boundary
element.definition: The start of the period. The boundary is inclusive.
element.comments: If the low element is missing, the meaning is that the low boundary is not known.

element.short: End time with inclusive boundary, if not ongoing
element.definition: The end of the period. If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing.
element.comments: The high value includes any matching date/time. i.e. 2012-02-03T10:00:00 is in a period that has a end value of 2012-02-03.

element.short: Organization that regulates and issues the qualification
element.definition: Organization that regulates and issues the qualification.

element.short: Relative, internal or absolute URL reference
element.definition: A reference to a location at which the other resource is found. The reference may be a relative reference, in which case it is relative to the service base URL, or an absolute URL that resolves to the location where the resource is found. The reference may be version specific or not. If the reference is not to a FHIR RESTful server, then it should be assumed to be version specific. Internal fragment references (start with '#') refer to contained resources.
element.comments: Using absolute URLs provides a stable scalable approach suitable for a cloud/web context, while using relative/logical references provides a flexible approach suitable for use when trading across closed eco-system boundaries.   Absolute URLs do not need to point to a FHIR RESTful server, though this is the preferred approach. If the url conforms to the structure
then it should be assumed that the reference is to a FHIR RESTful server.

element.short: Text alternative for the resource
element.definition: Plain text narrative that identifies the resource in addition to the resource reference.
element.comments: This is generally not the same as the Resource.text of the referenced resource.  The purpose is to identify what's being referenced, not to fully describe it.

element.short: A language the practitioner is able to use in patient communication
element.definition: A language the practitioner is able to use in patient communication.
element.comments: The structure aa-BB with this exact casing is one the most widely used notations for locale. However not all systems actually code this but instead have it as free text. Hence CodeableConcept instead of code as the data type.
element.requirements: Knowing which language a practitioner speaks can help in facilitating communication with patients.

element.short: Code defined by a terminology system
element.definition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
element.comments: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations, or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the V3 Core Principles for more information.  Ordering of codings is undefined and SHALL not be used to infer meaning.
element.requirements: Allows for translations and alternate encodings within a code system.  Also supports communication of the same instance to systems requiring different encodings.

Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should de-reference to some definition that establish the system clearly and unambiguously.

However this cannot consistently be assured. and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.
element.comments: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

element.definition: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).
element.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

element.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

element.definition: Indicates that this code was chosen by a user directly - i.e. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
element.comments: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations.
element.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact code was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

element.comments: Very often the text is the same as a displayName of one of the codings.
element.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human using them, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source.

mapping.map: C*E.9. But note many systems use C*E.2 for this

element.short: A name associated with the person
element.definition: A name associated with the person.
element.requirements: Contact persons need to be identified by name, but it is uncommon to need details about multiple other names for that person.

element.short: The list of Roles/Organizations that the Practitioner is associated with
element.definition: The list of Roles/Organizations that the Practitioner is associated with.

element.short: The Organization where the Practitioner performs the roles associated
element.definition: The Organization where the Practitioner performs the roles associated.

element.short: Roles which this practitioner may perform
element.definition: Roles which this practitioner is authorized to perform for the organization.
element.comments: A person may have more than one role. At least one role is required.
element.requirements: Need to know what authority the practitioner has - what can they do?

binding.name: PractitionerRole
binding.description: The role a person plays representing an organization

mapping.map: PRD-1 / STF-18-job title / PRA-3-practitioner category  / PRT-4-Participation / ROL-3-role-ROL / ORC-12-ordering provider / OBR-16-ordering provider / PV1-7-attending doctor / PV1-8-referring doctor / PV1-9-consulting doctor / PV1-17-admitting doctor
(ServD maps Practitioners and Organizations via another entity, so this concept is not available)

element.short: Specific specialty of the practitioner
element.definition: Specific specialty of the practitioner.

element.short: The location(s) at which this practitioner provides care
element.definition: The location(s) at which this practitioner provides care.

mapping.map:
(ServD maps Practitioners and Organizations via another entity, so this concept is not available)
However these are accessed via the Site.ServiceSite.ServiceSiteProvider record. (The Site has the location)

element.short: The list of healthcare services that this worker provides for this role's Organization/Location(s)
element.definition: The list of healthcare services that this worker provides for this role's Organization/Location(s).

element.short: Qualifications obtained by training and certification
element.definition: Qualifications obtained by training and certification.

element.short: A language the practitioner is able to use in patient communication
element.definition: A language the practitioner is able to use in patient communication.
element.comments: The structure aa-BB with this exact casing is one the most widely used notations for locale. However not all systems actually code this but instead have it as free text. Hence CodeableConcept instead of code as the data type.
